newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: FOCUS - Saudi term naphtha price seen toppish.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Saudi term naphtha price seen toppish.

text.p: Asian naphtha buyers said that soaring term prices were close to peaking in the wake of a record award by Saudi Arabia.
"Saudi Aramco has recognised the high value placed on ethylene and that endusers are willing to pay up," a Japanese trader said.
"But others have dropped out and the premium has reached the limit," he said.

The Middle East's biggest naphtha producer began negotiations in Singapore on May 12 to sell about three million tonnes of A-180 naphtha and between 1.2 and three million tonnes of full-range naphtha.
The sources said most buyers have agreed to pay a record premium of $17.00 per tonne over Saudi Aramco's formula for the ethylene-rich feedstock A-180, lifting from Ras Tanurah.
But buyers were reluctant to pay Aramco a target premium of $15 for low-paraffinic full-range material from Jubail and Rabigh ports, they said.

The current term contracts, for first half 1997, A-180 is priced at $6.50 and full-range at $5.50-$5.80.Saudi Aramco traditionally sells on a one year basis, but the price is reviewed after six months.
The reluctance of some buyers prompted Aramco to try to sell A-180 and full range as a package.
"Some existing Jubail lifters were said to have terminated contracts with Aramco due to the high price. As a result Aramco is still trying to sell some left-over Jubail," a trader said.
However, the A-180 allocation for each existing term holder was cut "substantially," from the previous year's volumes due to new buyers, such as South Korea's Hyundai Petrochemical said.

"The price is crazy," said one of the buyers. "Maybe from January 1998, the price will be lower," he said referring to the price review Aramco holds just before of the end of each year on term contracts.
"It is possible in six month's time, the premium will come down," a Japanese trader said.
Earlier this year, other Gulf exporters from Bahrain, Kuwait and Abu Dhabi capitalised on surging Asian petrochemical demand to clinch high premiums on term sales.

Kuwait achieved a premium of $13.50 per tonne over MidEast quotes for March 1997 to February 1998, while Bahrain National Oil Co achieved $11.00-$11.50 and Abu Dhabi National Oil Co (ADNOC) $11.50 for calendar 1997.

But the price spiral could have one further round to go, traders said. ADNOC has told Japan and South Korean buyers that it is seeking a premium for it high grade naphtha of $22.50 for July 1997 to June 1998, compared with $6.80 a year earlier.
Kuwait is also to start term talks on June 9 in London for the sale of naphtha for one-year from August.

"At this moment, everybody fears a tight supply situation with the start-up of new plants," said one buyer. "But next year, the reality will be there are so many arbitrage cargoes that there will no need to maintain term contracts with Middle East suppliers."
With contribution from Kiyoshi Takenaka in Tokyo.
